perturbation.original_text: element 5 shall be responsible for the entire order processing for the referred end user according to the terms and conditions of the underlying share-it! Developer Agreement between the Software Publisher and element 5. element 5 shall provide the order forms for the order processing on its Web server; receive payments from the referred end users and forward these payments, less the agreed Advertising Cost Compensation, the service fees and relevant value added tax (VAT) to the Software Publisher; handle refunds and returns according to the provisions of the underlying share-it! Developer Agreement; and provide end user service relating to the administration of the order.
perturbation.changed_text: element 5 shall be responsible for the entire order processing for the referred end user. element 5 shall provide the order forms for the order processing on its Web server; receive payments from the referred end users and forward these payments, less the agreed Advertising Cost Compensation and the service fees to the Software Publisher; and provide end user service relating to the administration of the order.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the explicit statement that element 5 handles refunds and returns according to the provisions of the underlying share-it! Developer Agreement, the contract omits a legally mandated consumer protection. German law (where element 5 is located) and EU consumer law provide specific rights to consumers regarding refunds and returns, particularly for online purchases. By not explicitly stating that these rights are handled according to the underlying agreement, the contract creates ambiguity and potentially weakens consumer rights.
perturbation.contradicted_law: German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch - BGB) §§ 312g, 355 regarding right of withdrawal for online contracts, and EU Consumer Rights Directive 2011/83/EU

perturbation.original_text: The parties exclude mutual liability for slightly negligent violation of obligations in connection with this agreement, with the exception of § 16 and § 5 (3) of this agreement. This includes in particular the liability exclusion for lost profit, the loss of data or interruption to or errors in the operation of the Web site of the Affiliate. The above liability exclusion also applies to the personal liability of employees, representatives and persons employed to perform the obligations of the parties to the agreement. The limitation of liability does not apply to claims arising through initial incapacity or in case of justifiable impossibility.
perturbation.changed_text: The parties exclude mutual liability for slightly negligent violation of obligations in connection with this agreement. This includes in particular the liability exclusion for lost profit, the loss of data or interruption to or errors in the operation of the Web site of the Affiliate. The above liability exclusion also applies to the personal liability of employees, representatives and persons employed to perform the obligations of the parties to the agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of the phrase 'The limitation of liability does not apply to claims arising through initial incapacity or in case of justifiable impossibility' weakens consumer protections under German law. German law does not allow for limitations of liability in cases of gross negligence or intentional misconduct. Omitting this carve-out implies that even in such cases, liability is limited, which is a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch - BGB) § 276 regarding limitations of liability for intentional misconduct or gross negligence.

perturbation.original_text: Even in case of agreements with foreign (non-German) Software Publishers and Affiliates, the law of the Federal Republic of Germany applies. The place of jurisdiction for all claims arising in connection with this business relationship is Cologne, Germany.
perturbation.changed_text: The place of jurisdiction for all claims arising in connection with this business relationship is Cologne, Germany.
perturbation.explanation: By omitting 'Even in case of agreements with foreign (non-German) Software Publishers and Affiliates, the law of the Federal Republic of Germany applies,' the contract becomes ambiguous regarding the applicable law. While specifying Cologne as the place of jurisdiction provides some indication, the omission allows for potential disputes over whether German law truly applies, especially if the Affiliate is based outside Germany and their local consumer protection laws offer stronger protections. This creates a legal risk because it undermines the consumer's understanding of their rights and the legal framework governing the agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: EU law requires clarity on applicable law and jurisdiction in consumer contracts to ensure consumers can effectively exercise their rights.
